none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, October 17, 1880
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, October 17, 1880
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 7 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
Brenham Texas.
Oct 17 - 1880

My Dear Professor

Your letter came to "hand"
some days since - Its perusal gave
us pleasure - I have not been well
for ten days or more - though mechanically
I go through the routine - I suppose ere
this you are Medias res - Well, we
struggle into the world - find it full
of activities - struggle through it, & struggle
out of it - often solicitous about our
name & our fame - which pass away
with our bodies - A few hasty spades
of earth are thrown over them - a few
sorrowing friends drop a warm sym-
pathetic tear - then join the busy throng
& struggle on - in turn drop out & the
world still moves on in its appointed
sphere - Two things at least seem to be
certain - We will reach our end at
the appointed time, & our sins will find us
out unless we are covered from the storm -

**My Transcription Process**

Okay, here we go. First, I need to get the header: "Brenham Texas," and the date, "Oct 17 - 1880." Right, that’s set. Now, the salutation, "My Dear Professor." It’s a formal letter. Next, to the body. "Your letter came to 'hand'." Okay, the word "hand" is in quotes. Must be important. It says, "some days since - Its perusal gave us pleasure - I have not been well for ten days or more - though mechanically I go through the routine - I suppose ere this you are Medias res - Well, we struggle into the world - find it full of activities - struggle through it, & struggle out of it - often solicitous about our name & our fame - which pass away with our bodies - A few hasty spades of earth are thrown over them - a few sorrowing friends drop a warm sym- pathetic tear - then join the busy throng & struggle on - in turn drop out & the world still moves on in its appointed sphere - Two things at least seem to be certain - We will reach our end at the appointed time, & our sins will find us out unless we are covered from the storm -".

The handwriting is cursive, a bit faded. The writer seems to be reflecting on life, death, and the fleeting nature of fame, really. The Latin phrase "Medias res" stands out; the writer is clearly someone of learning. The letter conveys a certain weariness, but also a sense of acceptance. It's an interesting bit of history. I think I've got it, let's format it nicely.

[1880, Oct 17]

I see from the papers that Dixon is dead –
He had some good impulses – but lacked
moral stamina to resist bad influences –
Whatever good name or fame he may
have achieved, I would not tarnish –
He has gone to his reward – he has
"decapitated" his last man – I trust ere
his summons came he saw his oppression
his sin against innocent men – & obtained
pardon – Had it been the head instead
of the tail of the kite, it were better –
Reason philosophy & common sense teach
us to look well to our own orderings &
to the things that are before us – but
you know how deeply I feel an
injury done me – I forbear –
You see from the papers that Clopper
of Houston died suddenly a few days ago
The irrepressible Alex. H. is making
application for the vacancy – has in
person made an exhaustive canvass
of the city – Would not be surprised
if he be successful

**Thought Summary for Transcription** Okay, here's how I'm going to approach this transcription. First, I need to understand the assignment. I'm a transcriptionist, and my task is to accurately reproduce the text from the image, following specific guidelines. I need to maintain the original spelling and punctuation, even if it's unusual, and preserve the line breaks. I'm also expected to deal with the handwriting, using "[?]" for anything I'm uncertain about. The client has specified *very* strict HTML tags - only `a`, `b`, `br`, `i`, `img`, `p`, `small`, `span`, `sub`, and `sup` are allowed. Now, I'll start with a scan of the image. It's a handwritten letter on lined paper. The handwriting is cursive and somewhat rushed, but mostly legible. There's a date in brackets at the top right, probably added later. The content appears to be about someone named "Dixon" who has died, some moral reflections, and news about someone named "Clopper" and "Alex H." I'll proceed line by line. The date, which is "[1880, Oct 17]", seems like a pencil addition. I need to remember the HTML restriction for this. * **Line 1:** "I see from the papers that Dixon is dead –" - seems clear. * **Line 2:** "He had some good impulses – but lacked" - also clear. * **Line 3:** "moral stamina to resist bad influences –" - clear. * **Line 4:** "Whatever good name or fame he may" * **Line 5:** "have achieved, I would not tarnish –" * **Line 6:** "He has gone to his reward – he has" * **Line 7:** "\"decapitated\" his last man – I trust ere" - the quotes are part of the original, "ere" means "before." * **Line 8:** "his summons came he saw his oppression" * **Line 9:** "his sin against innocent men – & obtained" - the ampersand is as written. * **Line 10:** "pardon – Had it been the head instead" - emphasis. I have to use `` for emphasis because `` is forbidden. * **Line 11:** "of the tail of the kite, it were better –" * **Line 12:** "Reason philosophy & common sense teach" * **Line 13:** "us to look well to our own orderings &" - the ampersand is as written. * **Line 14:** "to the things that are before us – but" - also emphasis, so this gets `` as well. * **Line 15:** "you know how deeply I feel an" * **Line 16:** "injury done me – I forbear –" * **Line 17:** "You see from the papers that Clopper" - I think it is "Clopper". This seems to make the most sense in context. * **Line 18:** "of Houston died suddenly a few days ago" - It looks like the end word might be slightly unclear, but "ago" seems the most likely. * **Line 19:** "The irrepressible Alex. H. is making" - Definitely emphasis on "irrepressible". It could be "Alex, H." or "Alex. H.", but the period is more likely. * **Line 20:** "application for the vacancy – has in" * **Line 21:** "person made an exhaustive canvass" - "canvass" not "canvas". * **Line 22:** "of the city – Would not be surprised" * **Line 23:** "if he be successful" I need to apply the HTML formatting now. I should use `

` for the date. It is the only way to adhere to strict formatting. The instructions explicitly disallow `align`. I must use `
` to preserve the original line breaks. Now, I have to re-read and double-check, looking for potential errors. Everything seems accurate, and I have addressed all guidelines. I will now build the final output. The main body of text will be in a single paragraph, with `
` tags to represent the line breaks. Ready to submit.

[1880, Oct 17]

Tommie Enckright has been here for
10 or 12 days – looking for a place –
I have done what I can to get him
a place – but Brenham has many
more applicants than places –
I fear Tom left home in a mad fit –
Let me know how the A & M C. is doing –
What is your enrollment & what is the
number in the Dept. by sufferance,
of Anct Languages? How is the industrial
feature likely to develop?
I feel rather gloomy over affairs
in Louisiana – My work is pleasant
here in many respects – Still, I am
inclined to prepare for an emergency –
which may present itself at some time –
Can you send me those MSS you have
on Eng. Literature? I will return
them after examination –
All in usual health except myself –
Pardon my delay & do not likewise
Our friend Moore is quite well –

[Signature] Your friend J. T. Hand

**Transcription Analysis and Formatting** Okay, here's the transcription. I've taken a good, long look at the image and the handwriting. My primary goal, as always, is to provide the most accurate representation of what's on the page. I've broken it down into a clear, formatted text.
